generic: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Hepatitis B Vaccine
drugs: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Hepatitis B Vaccine

0.title: Generic Names
0.mono: Diphtheria, Tetanus, Pertussis, Hepatitis B Vaccine

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis (whole cell), hepatitis B (rDNA) vaccine adsorbed (Tritanrix HepB) has centralized marketing authorization by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) for use in the European Union (EU)
  • Hepatitis B vaccination - Vaccination for diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus: primary series, 0.5 mL IM for 3 doses at intervals of at least 4 weeks, within the first 6 months of life; start as early as 8 weeks of age if hepatitis B vaccine not given at birth, and 6 weeks of age if hepatitis B vaccine given at birth (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)
  • Hepatitis B vaccination - Vaccination for diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus: booster, follow local recommendations for booster dose during second year of life (European Medicines Agency-approved dosing)
  • Hepatitis B vaccination - Vaccination for diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus: administer subQ to patients with a bleeding disorder or thrombocytopenia

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Hepatitis B vaccination - Vaccination for diphtheria, pertussis, and tetanus

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• encephalopathy of unknown etiology within 7 days after administration of previous pertussis-containing vaccine; continue diphtheria, tetanus, and hepatitis B vaccine administration
  • febrile illness, acute, severe; postpone administration
  • hypersensitivity after previous administration of diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, or hepatitis B vaccines
  • hypersensitivity to any of the active substances or any component of the vaccine

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• anaphylactic reactions may occur; observe vaccinee for 30 minutes after administration
  • bleeding disorder; bleeding may occur after IM administration; administer subQ
  • immunosuppressed patients (eg, use of immunosuppressive therapy); expected immunological response may not be obtained
  • neurological disorder, severe, new onset or progression of preexisting; consider benefits and risks of administering or deferring vaccination
  • subsequent doses of pertussis-containing vaccines should be reconsidered if a vaccinee develops any of the following events in temporal relation to administration: unexplained temperature of 40 degrees C or higher within 48 hours, collapse or shock-like state (hypotonic-hyporesponsive) within 48 hours, persistent crying lasting 3 hours or more within 48 hours, convulsions with or without fever within 3 days; re-administer pertussis-containing vaccine only if potential benefit outweighs risks (eg, high incidence of pertussis)
  • thrombocytopenia; bleeding may occur after IM administration; administer subQ
  • very premature infants (born 28 weeks of gestation or less); consider risk of apnea and need for respiratory monitoring for 48 to 72 hours after primary immunization series, especially in infants with a history of respiratory immaturity; do not withhold or delay vaccination

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono:
• Diphtheria Toxoid, Adsorbed: C (FDA)
  • Diphtheria Toxoid, Adsorbed: A (AUS)
  • Hepatitis B Vaccine Recombinant: C (FDA)
  • Hepatitis B Vaccine Recombinant: B2 (AUS)
  • Pertussis Vaccine: Fetal risk cannot be ruled out. (TH)
  • Tetanus Toxoid: C (FDA)
  • Tetanus Toxoid: A (AUS)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Diphtheria Toxoid, Adsorbed: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Diphtheria Toxoid, Adsorbed: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.
  • Hepatitis B Vaccine Recombinant: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Hepatitis B Vaccine Recombinant: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.
  • Pertussis Vaccine: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Pertussis Vaccine: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.
  • Tetanus Toxoid: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Erythema at injection site (38.9%), Injection site pain (32%), Swelling at injection site (30.9%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal symptom (1% to less than 10%), Infant feeding problem (10% or higher), Pharyngitis (1% to less than 10%)
  • Neurologic:Somnolence (10% or higher)
  • Otic:Otitis media (1% to less than 10%)
  • Psychiatric:Crying infant (10% or higher), Irritability (10% or higher)
  • Respiratory:Bronchitis (1% to less than 10%)
  • Other:Fever (53.1%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Collapse
  • Immunologic:Hypersensitivity reaction (less than 0.01%)
  • Respiratory:Apnea, In very premature infants

1.title: Synonyms
1.mono:
• Diphtheria Toxoid; Whole Cell Pertussis Vaccine; Tetanus Toxoid; and Hepatitis B Recombinant Vaccine
  • DPT and Hepatitis B Vaccine

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    • do not administer IV
    • administer subQ in patients with a bleeding disorder or thrombocytopenia
  • Intramuscular
    • shake vial well
    • administer by deep IM injection, preferably in the anterolateral thigh
